title-group.article-title: An improved trust region method for unconstrained optimization

article-meta.aff: Department of Mathematics, Jining University, Qufu, China

author-notes.corresp: Jun Liu, Department of Mathematics, Jining University, Xingtan Road, Qufu, Shandong Province, 273155, People's Republic of China Email: sdwslj@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, a new trust region method for unconstrained optimization is proposed. In the new method, the trust radius adjusts itself adaptively. In our algorithm, we use the convex combination of the Hessian matrix at a previous iteration and current iteration to define a suitable trust region radius at each iteration. The global, superlinear and quadratic convergence results of the algorithm are established under reasonable assumptions. Finally, some numerical results are given.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Consider the following unconstrained optimization problem (1)minx∈Rn f(x), where f: Rn → R is a twice continuously differentiable function.

At present, many algorithms have been proposed for solving (1), for example the Newton method, quasi-Newton method, the conjugate gradient method and the trust region method, etc. (Yuan and Sun 1997, see). These algorithms have good convergence properties if f satisfies some reasonable conditions. The trust region method was first proposed in the 1970s by Powell (1970). Owing to its strong convergent and robustness, trust region method had been studied by many authors (Schultz et al. 1985; Xu and Yang 1998; Gu and Mo 2008).

The trust region method is an iterate method. In every iteration xk, a trial step dk is obtained by solving the following quadratic program subproblem (2){minφk(d)=gkTd+1 2dTBkd,s.t. ‖d‖≤Δk, where gk = ▿x f(xk), Bk ∈ Rn×n is a symmetric matrix which is either the Hessian matrix of f at xk or an approximation of it, ‖·‖ refers to the Euclidean norm and Δk > 0 is the radius of an area, called the trust region, where the model is trusted.

The trust region radius Δk is independent of gk and Bk in the traditional trust region methods, this situation may decrease the efficiency of these methods. Furthermore, the initial trust region radius Δ0 also affects the efficiency of these methods. Therefore, it appears that an ideal trust region method should adjust the trust region radius automatically at each iteration. Many authors, such as Zhang et al. (2002), Hei (2003), Fu and Sun (2005), Li (2006), Shi and Guo (2008) and Sang and Sun (2009), have proposed adaptive trust region methods. The numerical results show that adaptive trust region algorithms are more efficient than traditional trust region methods for unconstrained optimization problems.

Motivated by the technique of Cui and Wu (2011), we give a new self-adaptive trust region method for unconstrained optimization problems. The main difference between the new algorithm and others is the form of Δk, we use the convex combination of B∧k and B∧k+1 instead of B∧k+1, which makes the results obtained by this form extend the conclusions of (Cui and Wu, 2011). On the other hand, in our method, we need not compute Bk-1 or B∧k-1, which can decrease the cost of computation. The global, superlinear and quadratic convergence properties of the new method are proved under reasonable assumptions.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In the next section we describe our new trust region method. In Sections 3 and 4, we prove global, superlinear and quadratic convergence of the algorithm under reasonable conditions, respectively. Some numerical results are given in Section 5. The results show that the new method is available and effective in practical computation. Finally, we give some conclusions.

sec.title: 2. The adaptive trust region method
sec.p: In this section, we propose a self-adaptive trust region method. At the kth iteration, we obtain the trial step dk by solving (2).

The actual reduction of f(x) is defined by Aredk=fk-f(xk+dk) and the predicted reduction of f(x) is defined by Predk=φk(0)-φ(dk), further, the ratio of actual reduction to the predicted reduction is (3)rk=AredkPredk.
Now, we describe the self-adaptive trust region method as follows.

statement.title: Algorithm 2.1.
Remark 2.1.
statement.p: In Algorithm 2.1, we choose Δk+1=min{μk+1‖dk‖2dkT[ρ2B∧k+1+(1-ρ2)B∧k]dk‖gk+1‖ ,Δ¯}, which does not introduce additional work compared with the trust region method only using B∧k+1.

statement.title: Remark 2.2.
statement.p: When Bk is a symmetric positive-definite matrix, set Bk∧=Bk; otherwise, Bk∧ satisfies the condition dk-1TBk∧dk-1=dk-1TBkdk-1+i‖dk-1‖2, where i is the minimum value which satisfies dk-1TBkdk-1+ i‖dk-1‖2>0.

sec.title: 3. Convergence of the algorithm
sec.p: In the last section we described a new algorithm; in this section, we establish the convergence of Algorithm 2.1 and make the following assumptions.

statement.title: Assumption 3.1.

list-item.p: The level set L(x0) = {x|f(x) ≤ f(x0)} is a closed, bounded set and f(x) is twice continuously differentiable in L(x0).
There exists M > 0 such that (4)‖Bk‖≤M, k=0,1,2,….

statement.p: Define I={k:rk<η0}, J={k:rk≥η0}, I~={k:r∧k<η0}.

statement.title: Lemma 3.1.
statement.p: Aredk − Predk = O(‖dk‖2).

statement.title: Lemma 3.2.
Lemma 3.3.
statement.p: Suppose that Assumption 3.1(i) holds and let {xk} be the sequence generated by Algorithm 2.1, then the sequence {f(xk)} is convergent.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: From step 4 and Lemma 3.2, we have f(xk+1)=f(xk),if k∈I ,f(xk)-f(xk+1)≥η0(φk(0)-φk(dk))if k∈J . =η0Predk>0, Since k either in I or in J, we can obtain (6)f(xk+1)≤f(xk), k=0,1,2,…, which implies that f(xk) ≤ f(x0), i.e. (7)xk∈L(x0), k=0,1,2,…. From (6), (7) and by Assumption 3.1(i), {f(xk)} is convergent.

statement.title: Lemma 3.4.
statement.p: Suppose that Assumption 3.1 holds and ‖gk‖ ≥ δ holds for all k, then there is a constant γ > 0, such that (8)Predk≥βγΔk.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: From Lemma 3.2 and by assumptions, we have (9)Predk≥β‖gk‖min{Δk,‖gk‖‖Bk‖}≥β‖gk‖ ×min{Δk,‖gk‖M}≥β‖gk‖Δk‖gk‖ΔkM+‖gk‖. The third inequality in (9) follows from min{|p|, |q|}(|p| + |q|) ≥ |pq|, for all real numbers p, q.
From step 6 and the boundedness of {‖gk‖}, we can assume Δk≤Δ¯ and ‖gk‖ ≤ d holds for all k. So we have (10)Predk≥βδ2Δ¯M+dΔk=βγΔk, where γ=δ2Δ¯M+d.

statement.title: Lemma 3.5.
statement.p: Suppose that Assumption 3.1 holds and ‖gk‖ ≥ δ holds for all k. Then Algorithm 2.1 is well defined, i.e. there exists a positive integer m, such that xk+m is a successful iteration point.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: We give the proof by contradiction. Suppose that the algorithm cycles infinitely at iterate M, which implies that (11)k∈I(k≥M).

From the definition of r∧k, we have r∧k<η0 holds for all k ≥ M + 1, therefore (12)μk=c0k-MμM and (13)Bk=BM, when k ≥ M. From steps 5 and 6, when s ≥ M + 1, we have (14)Δs≤μs‖ds-1‖2ds-1T[ρ2B∧s+(1-ρ2)B∧s-1]ds-1‖gs‖≤c0s-MμM‖ds-1‖2λmin(B∧M)‖ds-1‖2‖gM‖=c0s-MμM1λmin(B∧M)‖gM‖→0(s→∞), where λmin(B∧M) is the minimum eigenvalue of B∧M. Then from Lemmas 3.1 and 3.4, we get |rs-1|=Areds-Preds|Preds|≤O(‖ds2‖)βγΔs≤O(Δs2)βγΔs →0(s→∞), which implies that (15)rs≥η0, holds for sufficiently large s, which is a contradiction to (11). The theorem is thus proved.

statement.title: Theorem 3.1.
statement.p: In Algorithm 2.1, assume that Assumption 3.1 holds. Then for any ɛ > 0, Algorithm 2.1 terminates in a finite number of iterations.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: If the result is not true, there exists a constant δ > 0, such that ‖gk‖≥δ for allk. From Lemmas 3.3 and 3.4, we have (16)∞>∑k=1∞(f(xk)-f(xk+1))≥∑k∈J(f(xk)-f(xk+1)) ≥∑k∈J(η0βγΔk), Lemma 3.5 shows that J is a infinite set, so this and (16) imply that ∑k∈JΔk is convergent, and Δk → 0 as k → ∞(k ∈ J).

On the other hand, when Δk → 0, ‖dk‖ → 0, then for sufficiently large k ∈ J, |fk-f(xk+dk)Predk-1|=o(‖dk‖)+O(‖dk‖2‖Bk‖)Predk ≤o(‖dk‖)+O(‖dk‖2‖Bk‖)βγΔk→0. The inequality implies that there exists a constant μ* > 0, such that (17)μk≥μ* for sufficiently large k. From Remark 2.2 and Assumption 3.1(ii), we have ‖B∧‖≤2M+1, then (18)∞>∑k∈Jη0βγΔk≥∑k∈Jη0βγmin{μk‖dk-1‖2dk-1T[ρ2B∧k+(1-ρ2)B∧k-1]dk-1‖gk‖ ,Δ¯}≥∑k∈Jη0βγmin{δ2M+1μk,Δ¯}. Because J is a infinite set, then from (18) we infer that (19)limk∈J,k→∞μk=0, which is a contradiction to (17). The theorem is thus proved.

statement.title: Theorem 4.1.
statement.p: (superlinear convergence) Under Assumption 3.1, the sequence {xk} generated by Algorithm 2.1 converges to x*, where H(x*) is positive definite. If the following condition holds (20)limk→∞‖gk+H(x*)dk‖‖dk‖=0, then the rate of convergence is superlinear.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: From limk→∞xk = x*, we know that limk→∞‖dk‖ = 0, thus (21)limk→∞(xk+tdk-x*)=0. By the mean value theorem and (21), it follows that (22)gk+1-gk=∫01∇2f(xk+t(xk+1-xk))(xk+1-xk)dt=∫01∇2f(xk+tdk)dkdt=H(x*)dk+∫01(∇2f(xk+tdk)-H(x*))dkdt=H(x*)dk+o(‖dk‖), thus (23)gk+1=gk+H(x*)dk+o(‖dk‖). By (20) and (23), we have (24)limk→∞‖gk+1‖‖dk‖=0. Because H(x*) is positive definite and f is a twice continuously differentiable function, there exists M > 0 such that (25)‖gk+1‖=‖gk+1-g(x*)‖≥M‖xk+1-x*‖ for any k.

By (24) and (25), we have ‖gk+1‖‖dk‖≥M‖xk+1-x*‖‖dk‖=M‖xk+1-x*‖‖xk+1-xk‖ ≥M‖xk+1-x*‖‖xk+1-x*‖+‖xk-x*‖=M‖xk+1-x*‖‖xk-x*‖1+‖xk+1-x*‖‖xk-x*‖ and thus (26)limk→∞‖xk+1-x*‖‖xk-x*‖=0, which implies that {xk} converges to x* superlinearly.

statement.title: Theorem 4.2.
statement.p: (quadratic convergence) Under Assumption 3.1, the sequence {xk} generated by Algorithm 2.1 which converges to x*, where H(x*) is positive definite and H(x) is Lipschitz continuous in a neighborhood of x*, i.e. there exists a neighborhood B(x*, ɛ) = {x ∈ Rn|‖x − x*‖ < ɛ} of x* and L > 0, such that (27)‖H(x)-H(y)‖≤L‖x-y‖, ∀x,y∈B(x*,ɛ), if the following condition holds (28)limk→∞‖gk+H(x*)dk‖‖xk-x*‖2=0, then {xk} converges to x* quadratically.

statement.title: Proof.
statement.p: The proof is similar to that in Shi and Zhang (2005). In this case, Theorem 4.1 holds automatically. From (26) and limk→∞xk = x*, we have that there exists K such that for all k > K, xk ∈ B(x*, ɛ), xk+1 = xk + dk. It follows from (28) that gk+H(x*)dk=o(‖xk-x*‖2), i.e. dk=-H-1(x*)gk+o(‖xk-x*‖2). Let ξk = xk − x*. By the mean value theorem we have ξk+1=xk-x*+dk=ξk-H-1(x*)gk+o(‖ξk‖2)=ξk-H-1(x*)(gk-g(x*))+o(‖ξk‖2)=ξk-H-1(x*)∫01H(x*+tξk)ξkdt+o(‖ξk‖2)=H-1(x*)∫01[H(x*)-H(x*+tξk)]ξkdt+o(‖ξk‖2), which and (27) imply that ‖ξk+1‖=‖H-1(x*)∫01[H(x*)-H(x*+tξk)]ξkdt+o(‖ξk‖2) ≤‖H-1(x*)‖∫01‖H(x*) -H(x*+tξk)‖dt‖ξk‖+o(‖ξk‖2) ≤‖H-1(x*)‖L‖ξk‖2∫01tdt+o(‖ξk‖2)=1 2‖H-1(x*)‖L‖ξk‖2+o(‖ξk‖2). Therefore, limk→∞‖ξk+1‖‖ξk‖2≤limk→∞(1 2L‖H-1(x*)‖+o(‖ξk‖2)‖ξk‖2) =1 2L‖H-1(x*)‖, which shows that {xk} converges to x* quadratically.

sec.title: 5. Numerical results
sec.p: In the following, We report some numerical results of Algorithm 2.1 (NTR) and compared it with the traditional trust region algorithm (TTR) and the adaptive trust region method of Zhang et al. (2002) (TRZ). We chose the test problems from Moré et al. (1981). We choose η = 0.01 in test of TTR and c = 0.75, η = 0.01 in test of TRZ. The parameters in NTR are chosen as B0 = E, ρ1 = ρ2 = 0.9, η0 = 0.1, η1 = 0.8, c0 = 0.5, c1 = 2, μ0 = 1. The algorithm is terminated when ‖gk‖ is less than ɛ = 10−8.

From Table 1, we can see that our new self-adaptive trust region method needs fewer iterations or evaluations of functions than the TTR and TRZ methods for most of the problems, which indicates our new self-adaptive trust region method is efficient for solving unconstrained optimization problems. Table 1.
Numerical results of TTR, TRZ and NTR
TTR TRZ NTR
Problem ni/nf ni/nf ni/nf
Powell badly scaled 38/62 34/64 29/58
Gaussian 26/78 22/33 9/18
Trigonometric 91/94 81/89 71/87
Helical Valley 42/68 29/59 34/68
Wood 96/108 85/96 93/102
Biggs EXP6 53/72 32/32 28/32
Penalty I 85/91 64/68 48/58
Penalty II 81/86 66/74 52/90

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, we give a new self-adaptive trust region method for solving unconstrained optimization. We choose the radius with a new form which contains the convex combination of B∧k and B∧k+1 instead of B∧k+1. The new form can make the relation of current iterative information and previous iterative information more closed.

The sequence generated in our algorithm is monotonic nonincreasing, and this can considerably slow the rate of convergence in the intermediate stages of the minimization process, especially in the presence of the narrow curved valley. Therefore, for future research, we can give a nonmonotone self-adaptive trust region method to increase the convergence rate. On the other hand, in this paper the subproblem is a quadratic model, however, when the objective function has strong nonquadratic behavior, the quadratic model methods often produce a poor prediction of the minimizer of the function. For future research, the subproblem can be selected as a conic model.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The author wishes to thank the editor and the referees for their insightful and constructive comments, which improved this paper significantly.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
